page.title: 14THE GRAND UNION CANAL
page.content: The canal built in the 1700's which fell into decline with the coming of the railways, is a major feature of the area. The canal today remains open for recreational use. The banks, towpaths and bridges are in good repair. A feature of the canal is that it cuts the village of Catherine de Barnes in two with a road bridge connecting both. In one of the cottages by the canal is the remains of the original Boat Inn, a pub and hostel used by the bargees. It was destroyed by fire in 1923 and the present Boat Inn was built on the Hampton Lane in 1925. One of the residents for 70 years remembers playing a game called 'pigeon toss' while he waited for the old pub to open.
